awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Using an extreme climatological event to inform the evolutionary systems biology of thermogenic performance in deer mice.
awd_abstract_narration:
Two of the primary goals of evolutionary and ecological physiology are understand the mechanisms of physiological performance, and to assess the ecological consequences of individual variation in physiological traits. In this study, the PI will take advantage of a recent extreme cold weather event, the southward incursion of the polar vortex during the winter of 2013-2014, to extend his ongoing studies of the mechanistic underpinnings of thermogenic performance in high- and low-elevation populations of deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus). The PI's current research efforts (recently recommend for funding by NSF - IOS 1354934) are aimed at applying systems-biology approaches to develop and parameterize hierarchical computational models of the adaptive modification aerobic thermogenic capacity. In this study, he will complement these mechanistic insights with direct estimates of the strength of natural selection acting on various traits that influence whole-organism thermogenic performance. The brutal winter of 2013/2014 represents an extreme selective episode acting on thermogenic performance in small, winter-active endotherms like deer mice. As a result, the researchers have a unique opportunity to evaluate the strength of natural selection acting on traits that influence whole-organism thermogenic performance in the wild, and to directly incorporate data on selection intensities into their integrative analysis of the evolution of thermogenic performance. This study will provide key insights into the mechanisms underlying rapid phenotypic and evolutionary responses to severe climatic events.

Although many studies have documented phenotypic changes in response to putative selective episodes, none have used detailed mechanistic insights to predict which phenotypic traits are likely to be the targets of natural selection on this scale. The PIs ongoing mechanistic analysis of thermogenic performance will allow him to identify phenotypic and regulatory changes that are most likely to influence O2 flux and overall thermogenic capacity, while the work proposed in this study will allow the researchers to make direct connections between the intensity of selection acting on a trait and quantitative analysis of its regulatory control over pathway flux. The researchers will use  shifts in phenotypic trait means to formally estimate selection differentials acting various subordinate traits and regulatory network states that influence thermogenic performance under hypoxia. The combination of these lab and field studies will make important strides toward an integrated evolutionary systems biology framework for understanding adaptive variation in complex physiological traits.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research was to take advantage of an extreme weather event, the southward incursion of the polar vortex during the winter of 2013-2014, to extend ongoing studies of the physiological and genetic underpinnings of differences in thermal tolerance and aerobic performance between high- and low-elevation populations of deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus). The PI’s current research efforts are aimed using laboratory experiments to understand the physiological traits that underlie differences in aerobic performance under hypoxia and the genetic basis of these traits. This study complemented these mechanistic laboratory studies by adding estimates of the strength of natural selection acting on traits that influence aerobic performance, and the identification of genomic differences between the survivors the severe winter storms and their pre-storm ancestors. The brutal winter of 2013/2014 represented an extreme selective episode acting on thermoregulatory performance in small, winter-active endotherms like deer mice. As a result, it presented a unique opportunity to evaluate the strength of natural selection acting on traits that influence aerobic thermogenic performance in the wild, and to directly incorporate data on selection intensities into integrative analysis of the of the factors that influence aerobic thermogenic performance at high-elevation. 

Major results stemming from this award include the identification of a number of new candidate genes that likely contribute to variation in aerobic performance under hypoxia, as well as new analytical and genomic tools that will be of use to the broader ecological and evolutionary genomic community. These data also provided key “real-world” tests of mechanistic models that have been developed primarily through controlled laboratory experiments. The genomic and physiological results of this study provided novel, basic insights into physiological adaptations to high-altitude environments, and as such, may have implications for improving human health and performance at high elevation. This study also provided key insights into the mechanisms underlying rapid phenotypic and evolutionary responses to severe climatic events.

In addition to these scientific advances, this project involved two postdoctoral researchers, three graduate students, and several undergraduates. Given its multidisciplinary nature, this project is well-suited for integrative training of junior scientists. In the coming years, the major advances in most biological fields will likely come through cross-disciplinary studies that integrate across multiple levels of biological organization. This project is ideally suited for scientific training in this type of integrative biology, as it combines evolutionary and functional genomics with field studies and measurements of whole-animal physiology in an ecologically relevant context. Thus, for trainees wishing to pursue tenure-track academic positions, participation in a project like this will leave them well positioned to develop a highly integrative and innovative research program of their own, and trainees wishing to pursue careers outside of academia will be well-versed in a variety of modern approaches in integrative physiology and genomics. In addition to the specialized training and research skills they gained through their participation in the project, they also benefited from individualized mentoring plans that were tailored to their individual career goals and career stages.

Modified by: Zac Cheviron
